title: DAMPE
name: DAMPE
alttext: Artistic impression of DAMPE in order
descript:
The Dark Matter Particle Explorer (DAMPE) satellite, also known as “Wukong” (a reference to the Monkey King hero in the Chinese story “Journey to the West”), is a Chinese Academy of Science mission to measure highly energetic electrons and photons with high resolution in order to identify possible dark matter signatures.

The satellite was launched into a polar, sun-synchronous orbit with an altitude of 500 km on December 17, 2015. The Long March-2D rocket carrying DAMPE to orbit was launched from the Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center in China. At the start of operations, the mission was planned to have a three year service lifetime, but that was extended for a further two years in December 2018.
features: DAMPE observes the direction, charge, and energy of electrons and high-energy photons which would be generated when Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs, one of the candidate dark matter particles) annihilate: previous observations by other instruments have suggested this is a likely candidate for dark matter.
instrument_preamble: DAMPE is a single instrument mission. The detector contains multiple elements, stacked vertically atop each other along the Z (observational direction) axis of the spacecraft

instruments.name: Plastic Scintillator Detector (PSD)
instruments.descript: The PSD consists of a double layer of 1 × 2.8 × 82 cm staggered strips laid out in alternating layers of X and Y orientation. with a 82 × 82 cm total area. The PSD detects the charge of cosmic rays and also serves as an anti-coincidence detector for energetic photons. It has a position resolution of 6 mm and charge resolution of 0.25 for Z = 1–20. It also serves as a backup to the STK element.

instruments.name: Silicon-Tungsten Tracker (STK)
instruments.descript: The STK consists of multiple layers of silicon micro-strip detectors with interleaving tungsten converter plates. STK tracks the direction of gamma-rays by their conversion to charged particles in the tungsten plates, then tracking the particles through the instrument. STK has 6 tracking planes, each with two layers in X and Y planes, orthogonal to the instrument pointing. Cumulatively, this makes a sensor with 0.2° angular resolution at 10 GeV and the total silicon area is roughly 7 m<sup>2</sup>.

instruments.name: Bismuth-Germanium Oxide (BGO)
instruments.descript: The BGO calorimeter contains 308 bismuth germanate crystal bars, 2.5 × 2.5 × 60 cm, stacked in 14 layers in alternating X and Y direction orientations. A 0.5 mm gap around each crystal is filled with a silicone elastomer to hold each crystal in place and to prevent damage from launch vibrations. Incident particles interact with the crystals, generating a pulse of optical light which is detected by photomultipliers and each layer edge. The calorimeter is sensitive to energies between 5 GeV to 10 TeV.

instruments.name: Neutral Detector (NUD)
instruments.descript: The NUD consists of four large boron-doped plastic scintillation detectors, 30 × 30 × 1 cm in size. Each detector is equipped with a photomultiplier tube to measure light flashes causes by incident neutral particles exciting the boron and generating alpha particles and gamma-rays. The gamma-rays are converted to light pulses recorded by the instrument.

goals: Detect possible spectral features at gamma-ray energies indiciative of dark matter annihilation or decay
Study high-energy cosmic rays to obtain spectra and composition, with a focus on orgin and acceleration mechanisms
Observa high-energy gamma rays from astrophysical sources
Look for anisotropies in the arrival directions of cosmic-ray electrons and nuclei
